snippet.title: Cloud but slim chance of rain as big dry continues
snippet.content: THERE appears little relief on the horizon with the Sunshine Coast's bone-dry July likely to extend through August and into the start of spring. The latest Bureau of Meteorology data shows the Sunshine Coast received only a third of its average annual July rainfall after a particularly dry summer. July brought Queensland its highest temperatures on record with Kowanyama reaching 35 degrees on July 19. It follows a June rated the second-driest in recorded history in Queensland. BOM forecaster David Crock said temperatures remained warmer than average for the Sunshine Coast with no really strong signal of significant rain on the horizon. He said a strong system developing stretching from Cairns to Rockhampton may extend further south but was unlikely to reach below Wide Bay. Maroochydore's August average rainfall is only 80.5 mm. The Coast's minimum temperature remained above 10 degrees overnight ahead of an expected maximum of 22 degrees on a mostly sunny day with light winds. Thursday is expected to be partly cloudy with just a slight chance of rain and light winds with a maximum temperature of 23 degrees. Friday will be warmer still, topping 25 degrees on another partly cloudy day with no more than a hint of rain and with winds staying light throughout. Saturday is expected to be cloudy early with a medium chance of rain early ahead of a sunny afternoon on a day where the temperature will reach 24 degrees. Sunday is expected to be mostly sunny, on a day that winds will remain light with a 24 degree maximum and the possibility of late showers. Monday will see temperatures continue to climb, reaching 26 degrees during what is meant to be the depths of winter with light winds.
